body:
Unfortunately, I'm not able to replicate this at all. Your command line looks okay though. Perhaps it's a data issue? By default in the redesign branch, the generator extracts the `vol` variables from each npz file found in the training data directory.

After how many epochs does the loss drop to -inf?

I'll work on getting some working examples distributed. @adalca have we decided on what data to distribute yet?

@ahoopes First thank you for making the codebase openly available. 

I have been working on this since my comment above. I have managed to solve the -inf issue. Usually the best (lowest) loss value I get is 0.93 or 0.94, which (I think) is a minor improvement over ~0.98 loss value from my first epoch. I have tried epochs up to 500. 

These are the other things I have tried in vain:
1) increasing MRI volumes (up to 700 or so)
2) augmenting data by introducing random affine transformation


The model can perform good translation and possibly rotation, but *scaling* and **skewing**  do not work well (or at all). I can provide screenshot examples if it helps.  

Is the affine transformer expected to have scaling and skewing?

@adalca 

affine matrix is : 
```
array([[ 4.71396357e-01, -1.29300207e-02,  1.43270925e-01,
         1.15289450e+01,  1.70000400e-02,  5.24089158e-01,
         4.06596586e-02,  3.65229874e+01, -1.26412570e-01,
         4.63673025e-02,  2.01046973e-01,  6.92713776e+01]])
```

Rows (slices chosen based on the center of mass not mid-slices):
1) input or moving image
2) fixed image ( I have purposefully rescaled in my data augmentation)
3) Moved image (or transformed input image)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4290297/76635197-fde14c80-653e-11ea-82b9-e4b0933f1443.png)

Hi @armaneshaghi 

I guess I don't know that we've tested such exaggerated transformations, and perhaps we should -- but these are simulated, correct? Does the algorithm do very badly on real data?

thanks @adalca . 

Yes these are simulated. It fails similarly in real data. The reason to have simulated and exaggerated scaling was that the affine transformer was not learning scaling at all in real data, so I thought simulation might help, but it did not.
@armaneshaghi Could you show some real data example failures?

affine: 

```
array([[-4.16451506e-02, -5.90295233e-02,  4.61192429e-02,
         1.12353363e+01,  1.64070547e-01,  1.86138675e-02,
         4.44486961e-02,  2.19804173e+01, -7.39005059e-02,
        -3.22621502e-03,  1.65769190e-01,  5.57694855e+01]])
```
Rows (slices chosen based on the center of mass of the moved image):
- Input or moving image
- Fixed image ( I have purposefully rescaled in my data augmentation)
- Moved image (or transformed input image)



![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4290297/76637082-071fe880-6542-11ea-846e-bde912af1355.png)


Some trained models like your CVPR models to start with, could help to re-train.
Hm, while this isn't perfect, I am kind of confused about the comment of "the affine transformer was not learning scaling at all in real data" as it pertains to this example?
I should have said "scaling was not perfect". Thanks.
Yeah, that might be true. It would be interesting to (1) see how other methods (like ants, niftireg, etc) perform, and (2) aspects about your trianing -- how did the loss converge, etc?

The loss never went below 0.90, started from 0.98. Even after 500 epochs or so. The command line is what I used above with a change in Epochs (500). 

I have now added a fourth row with ANTs output using rigid+affine option in `antsRegistrationSyNQuick.sh` script. 

Rows:
- input or moving
- fixed
- moved by VM
- moved by ANTs

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4290297/76640515-fd997f00-6547-11ea-8421-1d3f77135fcc.png)

Thanks, but regarding the loss it would be great to see a graph, to understand how fast it was changing, how converged it was at the end, etc?

We'll look into this after the MICCAI deadline. We found the results to be very comparable with ants.

issue.title: Is affine VoxelMorph available?
issue.body:
I saw VoxelMorph model for **affine** transformation mentioned in #156 , #164 and some [other issues](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/issues/61#issuecomment-500231180), but haven't found it in the code. Is it available somewhere?
Thanks!
